ridgePlot

Source: R/ridgePlot.R
ridgePlot.Rd

The ridgePlot function generates a ridge density visualization for Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) results stored in a SummarizedExperiment object. Each ridge represents the distribution of ranking metrics for genes within a pathway, allowing intuitive comparison of enrichment signal patterns across multiple gene sets.

Usage

ridgePlot(
  seDataFgsea,
  showCategory = 10,
  breaklineN = 30,
  fill = "p.adjust",
  fontSize = 10,
  decreasing = TRUE
)

Arguments

seDataFgsea

A SummarizedExperiment object containing GSEA results, typically extracted using .extractDF(type = "gseaRaw"). The metadata must include enrichment statistics and ranked gene lists.

showCategory

Numeric or character. Specifies the number of top pathways to display or a vector of specific pathway names to include. Default is 10.

breaklineN

Integer. Maximum number of characters before inserting a line break in pathway names for readability. Default is 30.

fill

Character. Variable used for ridge fill color encoding. Must be one of "pvalue", "p.adjust", or "qvalue". Default is "p.adjust".

fontSize

Numeric. Base font size for axis text and titles. Default is 10.

decreasing

Logical. Controls the ordering of pathways along the y-axis based on the median ranking metric. If TRUE, sorts in descending order. Default is TRUE.

Value

A named list with two components:

ridgePlot

A ggplot2 object displaying ridge density curves of gene ranking metrics per pathway.

tableRidgePlot

A data.frame summarizing data used in the plot, including:

  • original_name: Original pathway name

  • label_name: Formatted pathway name with line breaks

  • raw_fill: Raw significance value (from the fill column)

  • neg_log10_fill: -log10 transformed significance

  • ranking_metric: Gene-level ranking values

  • median_ranking_metric: Median ranking value per pathway (calculated per group)

Details

This function provides a ridge plot visualization inspired by enrichplot::ridgeplot(), allowing flexible customization and unified color encoding.

The fill color of each ridge corresponds to -log10(significance) of the specified fill variable. Pathways are ordered by the median of their gene-level ranking metrics, and each curve represents the density of ranked genes for a given pathway.

Visual encoding:

  • X-axis: Gene ranking metric

  • Y-axis: Pathway names (auto-wrapped by breaklineN)

  • Fill color: -log10(p-value or adjusted value)

  • Ridge shape: Distribution of enrichment scores per gene set

Examples
